results.title: Elizabeth Riddell
results.creator_credit: John Erichsen, Australia Council and Royce Smeal Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Elizabeth Riddell came to Australia from New Zealand when she was eighteen. She recalls the community of artists and writers in Sydney in the 1930’s and her early experiences as a journalist. During the Second World War Riddell reported from North America and travelled through Europe. On her return to Australia, her long autobiographical poem was published. Riddell discusses the conflict between the demands of her career and her desire to write poetry. She speaks about the discipline of writing and the state of contemporary Australian literature.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Erichsen, Australia Council and Royce Smeal Film Productions

results.title: Coaching for improved performance
results.brief_description: In most organisations there are people who would benefit from training. This recognition, that improving employees performance is not a one off process, but one that should be continually developed, is crucial. This video provides managers and supervisors with the skills needed to become successful instructors, or coaches, in the workplace. The video follows a middle level manager in a typically structured organisation, who has recognised that a number of staff could benefit from coaching to improve their performance. Ten key skills of successful coaches are illustrated with practical examples. Pause breaks are included on the tape to allow for integration with the training guide.

results.title: Clydesdales
results.brief_description: Examines the physical build of the Clydesdale, indicating its suitability as a draught horse for haulage purposes. Also compares the use of these horses before and after mechanization.

results.title: Clouds
results.creator_credit: Arthur D. Nelles and Film Associates
results.brief_description: Points out to the primary school pupil the variety of observations that can be made about clouds: their appearances, shapes and the way they build up or fade away. Illustrates also the importance of clouds as a source of water. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Teacher behavior: an overview (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Phil Content, Patricia Heffernan-Cabrera and FilmFair Communications
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Interaction in the Multicultural Classroom”
Looks at the sorts of teacher interaction in the classroom which can either enhance or inhibit children’s learning. It stresses the need for teachers to search out behaviour patterns that encourage learning.

results.title: Withdrawal behaviour (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Gesa de Rozner, P. Hefferman-Cabera and Science Research Association
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Interaction in the Multicultural Classroom”.
Withdrawal is a response to overwhelming threat to identity. This film looks at behaviour in the classroom which can produce a withdrawal in both students and teachers, and indicates how to recognise this behaviour when it is occurring.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gesa de Rozner, P. Hefferman-Cabera and Science Research Association

results.title: Supporting behavior (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Phil Content, Patricia Heffernan-Cabrera and Science Research Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Interaction in the Multicultural Classroom”
We all need others to add their strength to our own. In the classroom pupils need support and guidance from teachers to give them the power to cope. A good teacher manages the classroom so that everyone gets a chance to express himself and grow.

results.title: Reciprocating behavior (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Patricia Heffernan-Cabrera, Phil Content and Science Research Association
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Interaction in the Multicultural Classroom”.
Because we are all dependent on each other, a voluntary exchange of personal ideas and emotions allows us to develop as individuals. Reciprocating behaviour in the classroom enables the pupils to develop, to become both receiver and giver.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Patricia Heffernan-Cabrera, Phil Content and Science Research Association
